content:
Pharmacotherapy during pregnancy is an important concern for a medical professional because there are only a limited number of drugs that can be safely administered during this period. Many drugs can cause harm to the fetus in the form of defects in organogenesis, growth retardation, and functional deficits. The aim of drug selection in this period is to prescribe an agent that effectively alleviates the mother's medical complaints while ensuring the safety of the unborn fetus. This article provides a brief overview of drugs that can be used for common conditions in pregnant women. It also lists the substances that should be avoided during pregnancy.

Antibiotics during pregnancy

Drugs of choice

  • Penicillin group : ampicillin, amoxicillin, flucloxacillin, penicillin V, propicillin
  • Cephalosporins
  • Macrolides: erythromycin, azithromycin
  • Metronidazole
  • Fosfomycin (see also: “UTI in pregnancy”)

Drugs to avoid

Overview of antibiotics to avoid during pregnancy [1][2][3]
Harmful side effects
Tetracycline
  • Inhibition of bone growth
  • Malformation and permanent yellow discoloration of the primary teeth
Aminoglycoside
  • Ototoxicity (CN VIII toxicity) and hearing loss
Trimethoprim/sulfonamide combinations
  • Cardiovascular birth defects
  • Neonatal jaundice (risk of kernicterus)
Chloramphenicol
  • Gray baby syndrome: a syndrome associated with chloramphenicol accumulation in the body, leading to ashen gray color of the skin, cardiovascular collapse, and abdominal distention
Clarithromycin
  • Potentially embryotoxic
Fluoroquinolones
  • Bone and cartilage damage

“Teethracycline:” teeth discoloration with tetracycline.
“A mean guy stepped on baby's ear:” Aminoglycoside can cause ototoxicity.

Antivirals during pregnancy

Drugs of choice

  • Acyclovir and valacyclovir for herpes
  • Oral oseltamivir and zanamivir for influenza
  • Zidovudine PLUS lamivudine PLUS nevirapine PLUS atazanavir for HIV infection (see “HIV in pregnancy”)

Drugs to avoid

Overview of antivirals to avoid during pregnancy [4][5][6][7][8]
Harmful side effects
Efavirenz [9]
  • Fetal neural tube defects
Ribavirin
  • Preterm birth
  • Significant teratogenic and/or embryocidal effects
Interferon α
Ribavirin and interferon α combination
Didanosine and stavudine combination
  • Lactic acidosis and hepatic failure leading to death
Nevirapine
  • Potentially fatal hepatotoxicity

Nevirapine should not be used as first-line therapy if avoidable!

Antifungals during pregnancy

Drugs of choice

  • Topical: imidazoles
  • Vaginal: nystatin
  • Systemic: amphotericin B

Drugs to avoid

Overview of antifungals to avoid during pregnancy [10]
Harmful side effects
Ketoconazole, flucytosine, and griseofulvin
  • Teratogenic and/or embryotoxic
Itraconazole, fluconazole (> 300 mg)
Iodides
  • Congenital goiter

Drugs of choice

  • Methyldopa in arterial hypertension and hypertensive crisis
  • Beta blockers (particularly metoprolol and labetalol)
    • Especially in the first and second trimesters
    • Avoid during the third trimester
  • Dihydralazine in uncontrolled hypertension
  • Nifedipine
  • See also: “Antihypertensives in pregnancy”.

“Moms Love Healthy Newborns:” Methyldopa, Labetalol, Hydralazine, Nifedipine are safe to use during pregnancy.

Drugs to avoid

Overview of antihypertensives to avoid during pregnancy [11][12]
Harmful side effects
Diuretics
  • Reduction of placental perfusion, particularly in the third trimester.
ACE inhibitors [13]
  • First trimester: cardiovascular and CNS malformations [14]
  • Second and third trimesters
    • Oligohydramnios
    • Fetal renal hypoplasia
    • Poor cranial ossification
    • Fetal death
Angiotensin-receptor blockers
  • Severe renal malformation
  • Oligohydramnios
Atenolol
  • Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR)
  • ↓ Placental growth
Usage of heart failure medications during pregnancy and lactation [15][16][17]
Class of drug Pregnancy Lactation
Loop diuretics
  • Use with caution.
  • Monitor blood pressure to avoid hypotension/hypovolemia, which may reduce placental perfusion.
  • Use with caution.
  • Monitor the newborn/infant's hydration status and weight gain.
Beta blockers
  • Use with caution (metoprolol is preferred).
  • Monitor the neonate for hypotension/bradycardia for 24–48 hours after birth.
  • Use with caution (metoprolol or bisoprolol is preferred).
  • Monitor the newborn/infant for hypotension/bradycardia.
ACE inhibitors
  • Contraindicated
  • Use with caution (enalapril or captopril is preferred).
  • Monitor the newborn/infant for hypotension, lethargy, edema.
Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist
  • Contraindicated
  • Spironolactone can be used with caution.
  • Monitor the newborn/infant's hydration status and weight gain.
Hydralazine/nitrates
  • Use with caution.
  • Use with caution.
Digoxin
  • Use with caution.
  • Use with caution.
ARBs
  • Contraindicated
  • Avoid.
ARNIs
Ivabradine

Drugs of choice

  • Heparin: anticoagulant of choice (does not cross the placental barrier)
  • Aspirin (ASA)
    • Low doses may be prescribed for high-risk preeclampsia.
    • High doses should be especially avoided in the third trimester

Drugs to avoid

Overview of anticoagulants to avoid during pregnancy [18][19]
Drugs to avoid Harmful side effects
Warfarin
  • Can pass through the placental barrier and may cause:
    • Spontaneous abortion, stillbirth, or preterm death
    • Cerebral hemorrhage leading to CNS abnormalities
    • Atrophy of the optic nerve
    • Bone deformities (e.g., stippled epiphyses, nasal hypoplasia)
Phenprocoumon
Non-vitamin K oral anticoagulants (apixaban, rivaroxaban, dabigatran)
  • The data available do not suggest a high risk of embryopathy, but, because of significant data gaps, they are to be avoided in pregnancy.

“Don't Warry, be Heppy:” warfarin should be replaced with heparin during pregnancy.

Drugs of choice

  • Non-opioid analgesics
    • Acetaminophen, especially in the third trimester
    • NSAIDs in the first trimester only
  • Opioid analgesics (e.g., fentanyl, codeine) for moderate to severe pain

Drugs to avoid

Overview of analgesics to avoid during pregnancy [20]
Harmful side effects
NSAIDs (in the second and third trimesters)
  • Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
  • Persistent pulmonary hypertension
  • Inhibits uterine contractility
Metamizole
  • In the first and second trimesters: increased occurrence of nephroblastoma in the embryo/fetus
  • In the third trimester: causes premature closure of the ductus arteriosus.

Drugs of choice

  • Antithyroid drugs
    • First trimester: propylthiouracil
    • Second and third trimester: methimazole
  • L-thyroxine

Drugs to avoid

Overview of thyroid agents to avoid during pregnancy [21]
Harmful side effects
Radioiodine therapy (absolutely contraindicated)
  • Ablation of fetal thyroid tissue leading to hypothyroidism
Methimazole (first trimester) Carbimazole Thiamazole
  • Aplasia cutis: a congenital dermatological condition characterized by the absence of a portion of skin in a localized or widespread area at birth
  • Craniofacial malformations (e.g., facial dysmorphism, choanal atresia)
  • Gastrointestinal malformations (e.g., esophageal atresia with or without tracheoesophageal fistula)

Drugs of choice

  • Individualized treatment based on seizure type and most tolerated drug
  • See “Epilepsy in pregnancy” for details.

Drugs to avoid

Overview of antiepileptics to avoid during pregnancy [2][22][23]
Harmful side effects
Phenytoin Carbamazepine
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome
    • Characterized by cleft palate, phalanx/fingernail hypoplasia, excessive hair growth, and intrauterine growth restriction
    • Due to impaired absorption of folate
  • Neural tube defects (carbamazepine only)
Valproate
  • Neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida)
  • Craniofacial dysmorphism

See “Antiemetic therapy for nausea and vomiting of pregnancy.”

This section provides an overview of drug classes to avoid during pregnancy. See also “Drugs to avoid” in each of the sections above.

Overview of other drugs to avoid during pregnancy [2][22][23]
Drugs to avoid Harmful effects
Steroid therapy (especially as antiallergenics)
  • Reduced birth weight
  • Increased risk of preeclampsia
  • Increased risk of oral and lip clefts
Oral antidiabetic agents
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Neonatal jaundice
  • Macrosomia
  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
Methotrexate
  • Neural tube defects
Cholestyramine
  • Fetal and maternal hemorrhage
Lithium
  • Congenital heart defects (particularly Ebstein anomaly)
Antineoplastic drugs (specifically antifolate metabolites and alkylating agents)
  • Congenital malformation of digits
  • Other malformations (e.g., neural tube defects)
Isotretinoin and excessive intake of vitamin A (> 8,000 IU vitamin A per day as retinol/retinyl esters)
  • High risk of miscarriage
  • Multiple congenital malformations, including cardiac anomalies, facial cleft, and skeletal abnormalities
Misoprostol
  • Abortions
  • Increased risk malformations [24]
    • Möbius sequence (bilateral congenital paralysis of the abducens nerve and facial nerve)
    • Hydrocephalus, encephalocele
    • Terminal limb reduction defects (e.g., clubfoot, syndactyly)
5α-reductase inhibitor
  • Increased risk of male genital malformation (e.g., hypospadias) [25]
Antacids Calcium carbonate
  • Increased risk of milk-alkali syndrome (hypercalcemia, metabolic alkalosis, and acute kidney injury) [26]
Magnesium hydroxide
  • Inhibition of uterine contractions [27]
  • Might delay the onset of lactation [28]

“IsoTERATinoin” is a TERrible TERATogen.”

First-generation antihistamines (e.g., chlorpheniramine) may be used as antiallergenics during pregnancy. Second-generation antihistamines (e.g., loratadine, fexofenadine, cetirizine) may be considered if chlorpheniramine is not tolerated. Loratadine is the best-studied second-generation antihistamine. [29]

Type 2 diabetes during pregnancy or gestational diabetes requires insulin therapy!
